segment_text: When I glance over my notes and records of the Sherlock Holmes cases between the years ’82 and ’90, I am faced by so many which present strange and interesting features that it is no easy matter to know which to choose and which to leave.
scene_description: indoors, wooden desk, stacked papers, soft lamplight

segment_text: Some, however, have already gained publicity through the papers, and others have not offered a field for those peculiar qualities which my friend possessed in so high a degree, and which it is the object of these papers to illustrate.
scene_description: indoors, wooden desk, stacked papers, soft lamplight

segment_text: Some, too, have baffled his analytical skill, and would be, as narratives, beginnings without an ending, while others have been but partially cleared up, and have their explanations founded rather upon conjecture and surmise than on that absolute logical proof which was so dear to him.
scene_description: indoors, wooden desk, stacked papers, soft lamplight

segment_text: There is, however, one of these last which was so remarkable in its details and so startling in its results that I am tempted to give some account of it in spite of the fact that there are points in connection with it which never have been, and probably never will be, entirely cleared up.
scene_description: indoors, wooden desk, stacked papers, soft lamplight

segment_text: The year ’87 furnished us with a long series of cases of greater or less interest, of which I retain the records.
scene_description: indoors, wooden desk, stacked papers, soft lamplight

segment_text: Among my headings under this one twelve months I find an account of the adventure of the Paradol Chamber, of the Amateur Mendicant Society, who held a luxurious club in the lower vault of a furniture warehouse, of the facts connected with the loss of the British barque _Sophy Anderson_, of the singular adventures of the Grice Patersons in the island of Uffa, and finally of the Camberwell poisoning case.
scene_description: indoors, wooden desk, stacked papers, soft lamplight

segment_text: In the latter, as may be remembered, Sherlock Holmes was able, by winding up the dead man’s watch, to prove that it had been wound up two hours before, and that therefore the deceased had gone to bed within that time—a deduction which was of the greatest importance in clearing up the case.
scene_description: indoors, wooden desk, stacked papers, soft lamplight

segment_text: All these I may sketch out at some future date, but none of them present such singular features as the strange train of circumstances which I have now taken up my pen to describe.
scene_description: indoors, wooden desk, stacked papers, soft lamplight

segment_text: It was in the latter days of September, and the equinoctial gales had set in with exceptional violence.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: All day the wind had screamed and the rain had beaten against the windows, so that even here in the heart of great, hand-made London we were forced to raise our minds for the instant from the routine of life and to recognise the presence of those great elemental forces which shriek at mankind through the bars of his civilisation, like untamed beasts in a cage.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: As evening drew in, the storm grew higher and louder, and the wind cried and sobbed like a child in the chimney.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: Sherlock Holmes sat moodily at one side of the fireplace cross-indexing his records of crime, while I at the other was deep in one of Clark Russell’s fine sea-stories until the howl of the gale from without seemed to blend with the text, and the splash of the rain to lengthen out into the long swash of the sea waves.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: My wife was on a visit to her mother’s, and for a few days I was a dweller once more in my old quarters at Baker Street.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “Why,” said I, glancing up at my companion, “that was surely the bell. Who could come to-night? Some friend of yours, perhaps?”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “Except yourself I have none,” he answered. “I do not encourage visitors.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “A client, then?”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “If so, it is a serious case. Nothing less would bring a man out on such a day and at such an hour. But I take it that it is more likely to be some crony of the landlady’s.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: Sherlock Holmes was wrong in his conjecture, however, for there came a step in the passage and a tapping at the door.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: He stretched out his long arm to turn the lamp away from himself and towards the vacant chair upon which a newcomer must sit.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “Come in!” said he.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: The man who entered was young, some two-and-twenty at the outside, well-groomed and trimly clad, with something of refinement and delicacy in his bearing.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: The streaming umbrella which he held in his hand, and his long shining waterproof told of the fierce weather through which he had come.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: He looked about him anxiously in the glare of the lamp, and I could see that his face was pale and his eyes heavy, like those of a man who is weighed down with some great anxiety.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “I owe you an apology,” he said, raising his golden pince-nez to his eyes. “I trust that I am not intruding.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: I fear that I have brought some traces of the storm and rain into your snug chamber.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “Give me your coat and umbrella,” said Holmes. “They may rest here on the hook and will be dry presently.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: You have come up from the south-west, I see.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “Yes, from Horsham.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “That clay and chalk mixture which I see upon your toe caps is quite distinctive.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “I have come for advice.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “That is easily got.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “And help.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “That is not always so easy.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “I have heard of you, Mr. Holmes. I heard from Major Prendergast how you saved him in the Tankerville Club scandal.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “Ah, of course. He was wrongfully accused of cheating at cards.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “He said that you could solve anything.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “He said too much.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “That you are never beaten.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “I have been beaten four times—three times by men, and once by a woman.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “But what is that compared with the number of your successes?”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “It is true that I have been generally successful.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “Then you may be so with me.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “I beg that you will draw your chair up to the fire and favour me with some details as to your case.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “It is no ordinary one.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “None of those which come to me are. I am the last court of appeal.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “And yet I question, sir, whether, in all your experience, you have ever listened to a more mysterious and inexplicable chain of events than those which have happened in my own family.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “You fill me with interest,” said Holmes. “Pray give us the essential facts from the commencement, and I can afterwards question you as to those details which seem to me to be most important.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: The young man pulled his chair up and pushed his wet feet out towards the blaze.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “My name,” said he, “is John Openshaw, but my own affairs have, as far as I can understand, little to do with this awful business.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: It is a hereditary matter; so in order to give you an idea of the facts, I must go back to the commencement of the affair.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “You must know that my grandfather had two sons—my uncle Elias and my father Joseph.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: My father had a small factory at Coventry, which he enlarged at the time of the invention of bicycling.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: He was a patentee of the Openshaw unbreakable tire, and his business met with such success that he was able to sell it and to retire upon a handsome competence.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “My uncle Elias emigrated to America when he was a young man and became a planter in Florida, where he was reported to have done very well.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: At the time of the war he fought in Jackson’s army, and afterwards under Hood, where he rose to be a colonel.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: When Lee laid down his arms my uncle returned to his plantation, where he remained for three or four years.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: About 1869 or 1870 he came back to Europe and took a small estate in Sussex, near Horsham.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: He had made a very considerable fortune in the States, and his reason for leaving them was his aversion to the negroes, and his dislike of the Republican policy in extending the franchise to them.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: He was a singular man, fierce and quick-tempered, very foul-mouthed when he was angry, and of a most retiring disposition.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: During all the years that he lived at Horsham, I doubt if ever he set foot in the town.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: He had a garden and two or three fields round his house, and there he would take his exercise, though very often for weeks on end he would never leave his room.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: He drank a great deal of brandy and smoked very heavily, but he would see no society and did not want any friends, not even his own brother.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “He didn’t mind me; in fact, he took a fancy to me, for at the time when he saw me first I was a youngster of twelve or so.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: This would be in the year 1878, after he had been eight or nine years in England. He begged my father to let me live with him and he was very kind to me in his way.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: When he was sober he used to be fond of playing backgammon and draughts with me, and he would make me his representative both with the servants and with the tradespeople, so that by the time that I was sixteen I was quite master of the house.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: I kept all the keys and could go where I liked and do what I liked, so long as I did not disturb him in his privacy.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: There was one singular exception, however, for he had a single room, a lumber-room up among the attics, which was invariably locked, and which he would never permit either me or anyone else to enter.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: With a boy’s curiosity I have peeped through the keyhole, but I was never able to see more than such a collection of old trunks and bundles as would be expected in such a room.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “One day—it was in March, 1883—a letter with a foreign stamp lay upon the table in front of the colonel’s plate.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: It was not a common thing for him to receive letters, for his bills were all paid in ready money, and he had no friends of any sort.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: ‘From India!’ said he as he took it up, ‘Pondicherry postmark! What can this be?’
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: Opening it hurriedly, out there jumped five little dried orange pips, which pattered down upon his plate.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: I began to laugh at this, but the laugh was struck from my lips at the sight of his face.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: His lip had fallen, his eyes were protruding, his skin the colour of putty, and he glared at the envelope which he still held in his trembling hand, ‘K. K. K.!’ he shrieked, and then, ‘My God, my God, my sins have overtaken me!’
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “‘What is it, uncle?’ I cried.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “‘Death,’ said he, and rising from the table he retired to his room, leaving me palpitating with horror.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: I took up the envelope and saw scrawled in red ink upon the inner flap, just above the gum, the letter K three times repeated.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: There was nothing else save the five dried pips. What could be the reason of his overpowering terror?
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: I left the breakfast-table, and as I ascended the stair I met him coming down with an old rusty key, which must have belonged to the attic, in one hand, and a small brass box, like a cashbox, in the other.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “‘They may do what they like, but I’ll checkmate them still,’ said he with an oath. ‘Tell Mary that I shall want a fire in my room to-day, and send down to Fordham, the Horsham lawyer.’
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “I did as he ordered, and when the lawyer arrived I was asked to step up to the room.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: The fire was burning brightly, and in the grate there was a mass of black, fluffy ashes, as of burned paper, while the brass box stood open and empty beside it.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: As I glanced at the box I noticed, with a start, that upon the lid was printed the treble K which I had read in the morning upon the envelope.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “‘I wish you, John,’ said my uncle, ‘to witness my will. I leave my estate, with all its advantages and all its disadvantages, to my brother, your father, whence it will, no doubt, descend to you.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: If you can enjoy it in peace, well and good! If you find you cannot, take my advice, my boy, and leave it to your deadliest enemy.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: I am sorry to give you such a two-edged thing, but I can’t say what turn things are going to take. Kindly sign the paper where Mr. Fordham shows you.’
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “I signed the paper as directed, and the lawyer took it away with him.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: The singular incident made, as you may think, the deepest impression upon me, and I pondered over it and turned it every way in my mind without being able to make anything of it.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: Yet I could not shake off the vague feeling of dread which it left behind, though the sensation grew less keen as the weeks passed and nothing happened to disturb the usual routine of our lives.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: I could see a change in my uncle, however. He drank more than ever, and he was less inclined for any sort of society.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: Most of his time he would spend in his room, with the door locked upon the inside, but sometimes he would emerge in a sort of drunken frenzy and would burst out of the house and tear about the garden with a revolver in his hand, screaming out that he was afraid of no man, and that he was not to be cooped up, like a sheep in a pen, by man or devil.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: When these hot fits were over, however, he would rush tumultuously in at the door and lock and bar it behind him, like a man who can brazen it out no longer against the terror which lies at the roots of his soul.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: At such times I have seen his face, even on a cold day, glisten with moisture, as though it were new raised from a basin.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “Well, to come to an end of the matter, Mr. Holmes, and not to abuse your patience, there came a night when he made one of those drunken sallies from which he never came back.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: We found him, when we went to search for him, face downward in a little green-scummed pool, which lay at the foot of the garden.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: There was no sign of any violence, and the water was but two feet deep, so that the jury, having regard to his known eccentricity, brought in a verdict of ‘suicide.’
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: But I, who knew how he winced from the very thought of death, had much ado to persuade myself that he had gone out of his way to meet it.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: The matter passed, however, and my father entered into possession of the estate, and of some £ 14,000, which lay to his credit at the bank.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “One moment,” Holmes interposed, “your statement is, I foresee, one of the most remarkable to which I have ever listened.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: Let me have the date of the reception by your uncle of the letter, and the date of his supposed suicide.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “The letter arrived on March 10, 1883. His death was seven weeks later, upon the night of May 2nd.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “Thank you. Pray proceed.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “When my father took over the Horsham property, he, at my request, made a careful examination of the attic, which had been always locked up.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: We found the brass box there, although its contents had been destroyed. On the inside of the cover was a paper label, with the initials of K. K. K. repeated upon it, and ‘Letters, memoranda, receipts, and a register’ written beneath.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: These, we presume, indicated the nature of the papers which had been destroyed by Colonel Openshaw.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: For the rest, there was nothing of much importance in the attic save a great many scattered papers and note-books bearing upon my uncle’s life in America.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: Some of them were of the war time and showed that he had done his duty well and had borne the repute of a brave soldier.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: Others were of a date during the reconstruction of the Southern states, and were mostly concerned with politics, for he had evidently taken a strong part in opposing the carpet-bag politicians who had been sent down from the North.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “Well, it was the beginning of ’84 when my father came to live at Horsham, and all went as well as possible with us until the January of ’85.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: On the fourth day after the new year I heard my father give a sharp cry of surprise as we sat together at the breakfast-table.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: There he was, sitting with a newly opened envelope in one hand and five dried orange pips in the outstretched palm of the other one.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: He had always laughed at what he called my cock-and-bull story about the colonel, but he looked very scared and puzzled now that the same thing had come upon himself.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “‘Why, what on earth does this mean, John?’ he stammered.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “My heart had turned to lead. ‘It is K. K. K.,’ said I.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “He looked inside the envelope. ‘So it is,’ he cried. ‘Here are the very letters. But what is this written above them?’
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “‘Put the papers on the sundial,’ I read, peeping over his shoulder.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “‘What papers? What sundial?’ he asked.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “‘The sundial in the garden. There is no other,’ said I; ‘but the papers must be those that are destroyed.’
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “‘Pooh!’ said he, gripping hard at his courage. ‘We are in a civilised land here, and we can’t have tomfoolery of this kind. Where does the thing come from?’
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “‘From Dundee,’ I answered, glancing at the postmark.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “‘Some preposterous practical joke,’ said he. ‘What have I to do with sundials and papers? I shall take no notice of such nonsense.’
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “‘I should certainly speak to the police,’ I said.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “‘And be laughed at for my pains. Nothing of the sort.’
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “‘Then let me do so?’
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “‘No, I forbid you. I won’t have a fuss made about such nonsense.’
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “It was in vain to argue with him, for he was a very obstinate man. I went about, however, with a heart which was full of forebodings.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “On the third day after the coming of the letter my father went from home to visit an old friend of his, Major Freebody, who is in command of one of the forts upon Portsdown Hill.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: I was glad that he should go, for it seemed to me that he was farther from danger when he was away from home. In that, however, I was in error.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: Upon the second day of his absence I received a telegram from the major, imploring me to come at once.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: My father had fallen over one of the deep chalk-pits which abound in the neighbourhood, and was lying senseless, with a shattered skull.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: I hurried to him, but he passed away without having ever recovered his consciousness.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: He had, as it appears, been returning from Fareham in the twilight, and as the country was unknown to him, and the chalk-pit unfenced, the jury had no hesitation in bringing in a verdict of ‘death from accidental causes.’
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: Carefully as I examined every fact connected with his death, I was unable to find anything which could suggest the idea of murder.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: There were no signs of violence, no footmarks, no robbery, no record of strangers having been seen upon the roads.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: And yet I need not tell you that my mind was far from at ease, and that I was well-nigh certain that some foul plot had been woven round him.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “In this sinister way I came into my inheritance. You will ask me why I did not dispose of it?
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: I answer, because I was well convinced that our troubles were in some way dependent upon an incident in my uncle’s life, and that the danger would be as pressing in one house as in another.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “It was in January, ’85, that my poor father met his end, and two years and eight months have elapsed since then.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: During that time I have lived happily at Horsham, and I had begun to hope that this curse had passed away from the family, and that it had ended with the last generation.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: I had begun to take comfort too soon, however; yesterday morning the blow fell in the very shape in which it had come upon my father.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: The young man took from his waistcoat a crumpled envelope, and turning to the table he shook out upon it five little dried orange pips.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “This is the envelope,” he continued. “The postmark is London—eastern division.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: Within are the very words which were upon my father’s last message: ‘K. K. K.’; and then ‘Put the papers on the sundial.’”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “What have you done?” asked Holmes.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “Nothing.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “Nothing?”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “To tell the truth”—he sank his face into his thin, white hands—“I have felt helpless.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: I have felt like one of those poor rabbits when the snake is writhing towards it. I seem to be in the grasp of some resistless, inexorable evil, which no foresight and no precautions can guard against.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “Tut! tut!” cried Sherlock Holmes. “You must act, man, or you are lost. Nothing but energy can save you. This is no time for despair.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “I have seen the police.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “Ah!”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “But they listened to my story with a smile. I am convinced that the inspector has formed the opinion that the letters are all practical jokes, and that the deaths of my relations were really accidents, as the jury stated, and were not to be connected with the warnings.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: Holmes shook his clenched hands in the air. “Incredible imbecility!” he cried.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “They have, however, allowed me a policeman, who may remain in the house with me.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “Has he come with you to-night?”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “No. His orders were to stay in the house.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: Again Holmes raved in the air.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “Why did you come to me?” he said, “and, above all, why did you not come at once?”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “I did not know. It was only to-day that I spoke to Major Prendergast about my troubles and was advised by him to come to you.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “It is really two days since you had the letter. We should have acted before this.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: You have no further evidence, I suppose, than that which you have placed before us—no suggestive detail which might help us?”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “There is one thing,” said John Openshaw. He rummaged in his coat pocket, and, drawing out a piece of discoloured, blue-tinted paper, he laid it out upon the table.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “I have some remembrance,” said he, “that on the day when my uncle burned the papers I observed that the small, unburned margins which lay amid the ashes were of this particular colour.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: I found this single sheet upon the floor of his room, and I am inclined to think that it may be one of the papers which has, perhaps, fluttered out from among the others, and in that way has escaped destruction.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: Beyond the mention of pips, I do not see that it helps us much. I think myself that it is a page from some private diary. The writing is undoubtedly my uncle’s.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: Holmes moved the lamp, and we both bent over the sheet of paper, which showed by its ragged edge that it had indeed been torn from a book.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: It was headed, “March, 1869,” and beneath were the following enigmatical notices:
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “4th. Hudson came. Same old platform.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “7th. Set the pips on McCauley, Paramore, and John Swain of St. Augustine.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “9th. McCauley cleared.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “10th. John Swain cleared.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “12th. Visited Paramore. All well.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “Thank you!” said Holmes, folding up the paper and returning it to our visitor. “And now you must on no account lose another instant.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: We cannot spare time even to discuss what you have told me. You must get home instantly and act.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “What shall I do?”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “There is but one thing to do. It must be done at once.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: You must put this piece of paper which you have shown us into the brass box which you have described.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: You must also put in a note to say that all the other papers were burned by your uncle, and that this is the only one which remains.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: You must assert that in such words as will carry conviction with them. Having done this, you must at once put the box out upon the sundial, as directed. Do you understand?”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “Entirely.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “Do not think of revenge, or anything of the sort, at present. I think that we may gain that by means of the law; but we have our web to weave, while theirs is already woven.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: The first consideration is to remove the pressing danger which threatens you. The second is to clear up the mystery and to punish the guilty parties.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “I thank you,” said the young man, rising and pulling on his overcoat. “You have given me fresh life and hope. I shall certainly do as you advise.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “Do not lose an instant. And, above all, take care of yourself in the meanwhile, for I do not think that there can be a doubt that you are threatened by a very real and imminent danger.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: How do you go back?”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “By train from Waterloo.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “It is not yet nine. The streets will be crowded, so I trust that you may be in safety. And yet you cannot guard yourself too closely.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “I am armed.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “That is well. To-morrow I shall set to work upon your case.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “I shall see you at Horsham, then?”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “No, your secret lies in London. It is there that I shall seek it.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “Then I shall call upon you in a day, or in two days, with news as to the box and the papers. I shall take your advice in every particular.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: He shook hands with us and took his leave. Outside the wind still screamed and the rain splashed and pattered against the windows.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: This strange, wild story seemed to have come to us from amid the mad elements—blown in upon us like a sheet of sea-weed in a gale—and now to have been reabsorbed by them once more.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: Sherlock Holmes sat for some time in silence, with his head sunk forward and his eyes bent upon the red glow of the fire.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: Then he lit his pipe, and leaning back in his chair he watched the blue smoke-rings as they chased each other up to the ceiling.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “I think, Watson,” he remarked at last, “that of all our cases we have had none more fantastic than this.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “Save, perhaps, the Sign of Four.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “Well, yes. Save, perhaps, that. And yet this John Openshaw seems to me to be walking amid even greater perils than did the Sholtos.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “But have you,” I asked, “formed any definite conception as to what these perils are?”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “There can be no question as to their nature,” he answered.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “Then what are they? Who is this K. K. K., and why does he pursue this unhappy family?”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: Sherlock Holmes closed his eyes and placed his elbows upon the arms of his chair, with his finger-tips together.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “The ideal reasoner,” he remarked, “would, when he had once been shown a single fact in all its bearings, deduce from it not only all the chain of events which led up to it but also all the results which would follow from it.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: As Cuvier could correctly describe a whole animal by the contemplation of a single bone, so the observer who has thoroughly understood one link in a series of incidents should be able to accurately state all the other ones, both before and after.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: We have not yet grasped the results which the reason alone can attain to. Problems may be solved in the study which have baffled all those who have sought a solution by the aid of their senses.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: To carry the art, however, to its highest pitch, it is necessary that the reasoner should be able to utilise all the facts which have come to his knowledge; and this in itself implies, as you will readily see, a possession of all knowledge, which, even in these days of free education and encyclopædias, is a somewhat rare accomplishment.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: It is not so impossible, however, that a man should possess all knowledge which is likely to be useful to him in his work, and this I have endeavoured in my case to do.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: If I remember rightly, you on one occasion, in the early days of our friendship, defined my limits in a very precise fashion.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “Yes,” I answered, laughing. “It was a singular document.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: Philosophy, astronomy, and politics were marked at zero, I remember. Botany variable, geology profound as regards the mud-stains from any region within fifty miles of town, chemistry eccentric, anatomy unsystematic, sensational literature and crime records unique, violin-player, boxer, swordsman, lawyer, and self-poisoner by cocaine and tobacco.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: Those, I think, were the main points of my analysis.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: Holmes grinned at the last item. “Well,” he said, “I say now, as I said then, that a man should keep his little brain-attic stocked with all the furniture that he is likely to use, and the rest he can put away in the lumber-room of his library, where he can get it if he wants it.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: Now, for such a case as the one which has been submitted to us to-night, we need certainly to muster all our resources.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: Kindly hand me down the letter K of the _American Encyclopædia_ which stands upon the shelf beside you. Thank you.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: Now let us consider the situation and see what may be deduced from it. In the first place, we may start with a strong presumption that Colonel Openshaw had some very strong reason for leaving America.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: Men at his time of life do not change all their habits and exchange willingly the charming climate of Florida for the lonely life of an English provincial town.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: His extreme love of solitude in England suggests the idea that he was in fear of someone or something, so we may assume as a working hypothesis that it was fear of someone or something which drove him from America.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: As to what it was he feared, we can only deduce that by considering the formidable letters which were received by himself and his successors. Did you remark the postmarks of those letters?”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “The first was from Pondicherry, the second from Dundee, and the third from London.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “From East London. What do you deduce from that?”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “They are all seaports. That the writer was on board of a ship.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “Excellent. We have already a clue. There can be no doubt that the probability—the strong probability—is that the writer was on board of a ship.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: And now let us consider another point. In the case of Pondicherry, seven weeks elapsed between the threat and its fulfilment, in Dundee it was only some three or four days.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: Does that suggest anything?”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “A greater distance to travel.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “But the letter had also a greater distance to come.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “Then I do not see the point.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “There is at least a presumption that the vessel in which the man or men are is a sailing-ship.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: It looks as if they always send their singular warning or token before them when starting upon their mission. You see how quickly the deed followed the sign when it came from Dundee.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: If they had come from Pondicherry in a steamer they would have arrived almost as soon as their letter. But, as a matter of fact, seven weeks elapsed.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: I think that those seven weeks represented the difference between the mail-boat which brought the letter and the sailing vessel which brought the writer.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “It is possible.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “More than that. It is probable. And now you see the deadly urgency of this new case, and why I urged young Openshaw to caution.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: The blow has always fallen at the end of the time which it would take the senders to travel the distance. But this one comes from London, and therefore we cannot count upon delay.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “Good God!” I cried. “What can it mean, this relentless persecution?”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “The papers which Openshaw carried are obviously of vital importance to the person or persons in the sailing-ship. I think that it is quite clear that there must be more than one of them.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: A single man could not have carried out two deaths in such a way as to deceive a coroner’s jury. There must have been several in it, and they must have been men of resource and determination.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: Their papers they mean to have, be the holder of them who it may. In this way you see K. K. K. ceases to be the initials of an individual and becomes the badge of a society.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “But of what society?”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “Have you never—” said Sherlock Holmes, bending forward and sinking his voice—“have you never heard of the Ku Klux Klan?”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “I never have.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: Holmes turned over the leaves of the book upon his knee. “Here it is,” said he presently:
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “‘Ku Klux Klan. A name derived from the fanciful resemblance to the sound produced by cocking a rifle.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: This terrible secret society was formed by some ex-Confederate soldiers in the Southern states after the Civil War, and it rapidly formed local branches in different parts of the country, notably in Tennessee, Louisiana, the Carolinas, Georgia, and Florida.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: Its power was used for political purposes, principally for the terrorising of the negro voters and the murdering and driving from the country of those who were opposed to its views.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: Its outrages were usually preceded by a warning sent to the marked man in some fantastic but generally recognised shape—a sprig of oak-leaves in some parts, melon seeds or orange pips in others.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: On receiving this the victim might either openly abjure his former ways, or might fly from the country.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: If he braved the matter out, death would unfailingly come upon him, and usually in some strange and unforeseen manner.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: So perfect was the organisation of the society, and so systematic its methods, that there is hardly a case upon record where any man succeeded in braving it with impunity, or in which any of its outrages were traced home to the perpetrators.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: For some years the organisation flourished in spite of the efforts of the United States government and of the better classes of the community in the South.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: Eventually, in the year 1869, the movement rather suddenly collapsed, although there have been sporadic outbreaks of the same sort since that date.’
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “You will observe,” said Holmes, laying down the volume, “that the sudden breaking up of the society was coincident with the disappearance of Openshaw from America with their papers.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: It may well have been cause and effect. It is no wonder that he and his family have some of the more implacable spirits upon their track.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: You can understand that this register and diary may implicate some of the first men in the South, and that there may be many who will not sleep easy at night until it is recovered.”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “Then the page we have seen—”
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: “Is such as we might expect. It ran, if I remember right, ‘sent the pips to A, B, and C’—that is, sent the society’s warning to them.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: Then there are successive entries that A and B cleared, or left the country, and finally that C was visited, with, I fear, a sinister result for C.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: Well, I think, Doctor, that we may let some light into this dark place, and I believe that the only chance young Openshaw has in the meantime is to do what I have told him.
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: There is nothing more to be said or to be done to-night, so hand me over my violin and let us try to forget
scene_description: indoors, roaring fireplace, rain-lashed windows, Victorian armchairs

segment_text: for half an hour the miserable weather and the still more miserable ways of our fellow men.”
scene_description: indoors, Victorian breakfast room, sunlit window, newspaper on table

segment_text: It had cleared in the morning, and the sun was shining with a subdued brightness through the dim veil which hangs over the great city.
scene_description: indoors, Victorian breakfast room, sunlit window, newspaper on table

segment_text: Sherlock Holmes was already at breakfast when I came down.
scene_description: indoors, Victorian breakfast room, sunlit window, newspaper on table

segment_text: “You will excuse me for not waiting for you,” said he; “I have, I foresee, a very busy day before me in looking into this case of young Openshaw’s.”
scene_description: indoors, Victorian breakfast room, sunlit window, newspaper on table

segment_text: “What steps will you take?” I asked.
scene_description: indoors, Victorian breakfast room, sunlit window, newspaper on table

segment_text: “It will very much depend upon the results of my first inquiries. I may have to go down to Horsham, after all.”
scene_description: indoors, Victorian breakfast room, sunlit window, newspaper on table

segment_text: “You will not go there first?”
scene_description: indoors, Victorian breakfast room, sunlit window, newspaper on table

segment_text: “No, I shall commence with the City. Just ring the bell and the maid will bring up your coffee.”
scene_description: indoors, Victorian breakfast room, sunlit window, newspaper on table

segment_text: As I waited, I lifted the unopened newspaper from the table and glanced my eye over it.
scene_description: indoors, Victorian breakfast room, sunlit window, newspaper on table

segment_text: It rested upon a heading which sent a chill to my heart.
scene_description: indoors, Victorian breakfast room, sunlit window, newspaper on table

segment_text: “Holmes,” I cried, “you are too late.”
scene_description: indoors, Victorian breakfast room, sunlit window, newspaper on table

segment_text: “Ah!” said he, laying down his cup, “I feared as much. How was it done?”
scene_description: indoors, Victorian breakfast room, sunlit window, newspaper on table

segment_text: He spoke calmly, but I could see that he was deeply moved.
scene_description: indoors, Victorian breakfast room, sunlit window, newspaper on table

segment_text: “My eye caught the name of Openshaw, and the heading ‘Tragedy Near Waterloo Bridge.’ Here is the account:
scene_description: indoors, Victorian breakfast room, sunlit window, newspaper on table

segment_text: “‘Between nine and ten last night Police-Constable Cook, of the H Division, on duty near Waterloo Bridge, heard a cry for help and a splash in the water.
scene_description: indoors, Victorian breakfast room, sunlit window, newspaper on table

segment_text: The night, however, was extremely dark and stormy, so that, in spite of the help of several passers-by, it was quite impossible to effect a rescue.
scene_description: indoors, Victorian breakfast room, sunlit window, newspaper on table

segment_text: The alarm, however, was given, and, by the aid of the water-police, the body was eventually recovered.
scene_description: indoors, Victorian breakfast room, sunlit window, newspaper on table

segment_text: It proved to be that of a young gentleman whose name, as it appears from an envelope which was found in his pocket, was John Openshaw, and whose residence is near Horsham.
scene_description: indoors, Victorian breakfast room, sunlit window, newspaper on table

segment_text: It is conjectured that he may have been hurrying down to catch the last train from Waterloo Station, and that in his haste and the extreme darkness he missed his path and walked over the edge of one of the small landing-places for river steamboats.
scene_description: indoors, Victorian breakfast room, sunlit window, newspaper on table

segment_text: The body exhibited no traces of violence, and there can be no doubt that the deceased had been the victim of an unfortunate accident, which should have the effect of calling the attention of the authorities to the condition of the riverside landing-stages.’”
scene_description: indoors, Victorian breakfast room, sunlit window, newspaper on table

segment_text: We sat in silence for some minutes, Holmes more depressed and shaken than I had ever seen him.
scene_description: indoors, Victorian breakfast room, sunlit window, newspaper on table

segment_text: “That hurts my pride, Watson,” he said at last. “It is a petty feeling, no doubt, but it hurts my pride.
scene_description: indoors, Victorian breakfast room, sunlit window, newspaper on table

segment_text: It becomes a personal matter with me now, and, if God sends me health, I shall set my hand upon this gang.
scene_description: indoors, Victorian breakfast room, sunlit window, newspaper on table

segment_text: That he should come to me for help, and that I should send him away to his death—!”
scene_description: indoors, Victorian breakfast room, sunlit window, newspaper on table

segment_text: He sprang from his chair and paced about the room in uncontrollable agitation, with a flush upon his sallow cheeks and a nervous clasping and unclasping of his long thin hands.
scene_description: indoors, Victorian breakfast room, sunlit window, newspaper on table

segment_text: “They must be cunning devils,” he exclaimed at last. “How could they have decoyed him down there?
scene_description: indoors, Victorian breakfast room, sunlit window, newspaper on table

segment_text: The Embankment is not on the direct line to the station. The bridge, no doubt, was too crowded, even on such a night, for their purpose.
scene_description: indoors, Victorian breakfast room, sunlit window, newspaper on table

segment_text: Well, Watson, we shall see who will win in the long run. I am going out now!”
scene_description: indoors, Victorian breakfast room, sunlit window, newspaper on table

segment_text: “To the police?”
scene_description: indoors, Victorian breakfast room, sunlit window, newspaper on table

segment_text: “No; I shall be my own police. When I have spun the web they may take the flies, but not before.”
scene_description: indoors, Victorian breakfast room, sunlit window, newspaper on table

segment_text: All day I was engaged in my professional work, and it was late in the evening before I returned to Baker Street.
scene_description: indoors, Victorian sitting room, lamplit, sideboard with loaf

segment_text: Sherlock Holmes had not come back yet.
scene_description: indoors, Victorian sitting room, lamplit, sideboard with loaf

segment_text: It was nearly ten o’clock before he entered, looking pale and worn.
scene_description: indoors, Victorian sitting room, lamplit, sideboard with loaf

segment_text: He walked up to the sideboard, and tearing a piece from the loaf he devoured it voraciously, washing it down with a long draught of water.
scene_description: indoors, Victorian sitting room, lamplit, sideboard with loaf

segment_text: “You are hungry,” I remarked.
scene_description: indoors, Victorian sitting room, lamplit, sideboard with loaf

segment_text: “Starving. It had escaped my memory.
scene_description: indoors, Victorian sitting room, lamplit, sideboard with loaf

segment_text: I have had nothing since breakfast.”
scene_description: indoors, Victorian sitting room, lamplit, sideboard with loaf

segment_text: “Nothing?” “Not a bite. I had no time to think of it.”
scene_description: indoors, Victorian sitting room, lamplit, sideboard with loaf

segment_text: “And how have you succeeded?” “Well.”
scene_description: indoors, Victorian sitting room, lamplit, sideboard with loaf

segment_text: “You have a clue?”
scene_description: indoors, Victorian sitting room, lamplit, sideboard with loaf

segment_text: “I have them in the hollow of my hand. Young Openshaw shall not long remain unavenged.
scene_description: indoors, Victorian sitting room, lamplit, sideboard with loaf

segment_text: Why, Watson, let us put their own devilish trade-mark upon them. It is well thought of!”
scene_description: indoors, Victorian sitting room, lamplit, sideboard with loaf

segment_text: “What do you mean?”
scene_description: indoors, Victorian sitting room, lamplit, sideboard with loaf

segment_text: He took an orange from the cupboard, and tearing it to pieces he squeezed out the pips upon the table.
scene_description: indoors, Victorian sitting room, lamplit, sideboard with loaf

segment_text: Of these he took five and thrust them into an envelope. On the inside of the flap he wrote “S. H. for J. O.”
scene_description: indoors, Victorian sitting room, lamplit, sideboard with loaf

segment_text: Then he sealed it and addressed it to “Captain James Calhoun, Barque Lone Star, Savannah, Georgia.”
scene_description: indoors, Victorian sitting room, lamplit, sideboard with loaf

segment_text: “That will await him when he enters port,” said he, chuckling. “It may give him a sleepless night.
scene_description: indoors, Victorian sitting room, lamplit, sideboard with loaf

segment_text: He will find it as sure a precursor of his fate as Openshaw did before him.”
scene_description: indoors, Victorian sitting room, lamplit, sideboard with loaf

segment_text: “And who is this Captain Calhoun?”
scene_description: indoors, Victorian sitting room, lamplit, sideboard with loaf

segment_text: “The leader of the gang. I shall have the others, but he first.”
scene_description: indoors, Victorian sitting room, lamplit, sideboard with loaf

segment_text: “How did you trace it, then?”
scene_description: indoors, Victorian sitting room, lamplit, sideboard with loaf

segment_text: He took a large sheet of paper from his pocket, all covered with dates and names.
scene_description: indoors, Victorian sitting room, lamplit, sideboard with loaf

segment_text: “I have spent the whole day,” said he, “over Lloyd’s registers and files of the old papers, following the future career of every vessel which touched at Pondicherry in January and February in ’83.
scene_description: indoors, Victorian sitting room, lamplit, sideboard with loaf

segment_text: There were thirty-six ships of fair tonnage which were reported there during those months.
scene_description: indoors, Victorian sitting room, lamplit, sideboard with loaf

segment_text: Of these, one, the Lone Star, instantly attracted my attention, since, although it was reported as having cleared from London, the name is that which is given to one of the states of the Union.”
scene_description: indoors, Victorian sitting room, lamplit, sideboard with loaf

segment_text: “Texas, I think.”
scene_description: indoors, Victorian sitting room, lamplit, sideboard with loaf

segment_text: “I was not and am not sure which; but I knew that the ship must have an American origin.”
scene_description: indoors, Victorian sitting room, lamplit, sideboard with loaf

segment_text: “What then?”
scene_description: indoors, Victorian sitting room, lamplit, sideboard with loaf

segment_text: “I searched the Dundee records, and when I found that the barque Lone Star was there in January, ’85, my suspicion became a certainty.
scene_description: indoors, Victorian sitting room, lamplit, sideboard with loaf

segment_text: I then inquired as to the vessels which lay at present in the port of London.”
scene_description: indoors, Victorian sitting room, lamplit, sideboard with loaf

segment_text: “Yes?”
scene_description: indoors, Victorian sitting room, lamplit, sideboard with loaf

segment_text: “The Lone Star had arrived here last week. I went down to the Albert Dock and found that she had been taken down the river by the early tide this morning, homeward bound to Savannah.
scene_description: indoors, Victorian sitting room, lamplit, sideboard with loaf

segment_text: I wired to Gravesend and learned that she had passed some time ago, and as the wind is easterly I have no doubt that she is now past the Goodwins and not very far from the Isle of Wight.”
scene_description: indoors, Victorian sitting room, lamplit, sideboard with loaf

segment_text: “What will you do, then?”
scene_description: indoors, Victorian sitting room, lamplit, sideboard with loaf

segment_text: “Oh, I have my hand upon him. He and the two mates, are as I learn, the only native-born Americans in the ship.
scene_description: indoors, Victorian sitting room, lamplit, sideboard with loaf

segment_text: The others are Finns and Germans. I know, also, that they were all three away from the ship last night.
scene_description: indoors, Victorian sitting room, lamplit, sideboard with loaf

segment_text: I had it from the stevedore who has been loading their cargo.
scene_description: indoors, Victorian sitting room, lamplit, sideboard with loaf

segment_text: By the time that their sailing-ship reaches Savannah the mail-boat will have carried this letter, and the cable will have informed the police of Savannah that these three gentlemen are badly wanted here upon a charge of murder.”
scene_description: indoors, Victorian sitting room, lamplit, sideboard with loaf

segment_text: There is ever a flaw, however, in the best laid of human plans, and the murderers of John Openshaw were never to receive the orange pips which would show them that another, as cunning and as resolute as themselves, was upon their track.
scene_description: outdoors, stormy ocean, dark waves, shattered wood debris

segment_text: Very long and very severe were the equinoctial gales that year.
scene_description: outdoors, stormy ocean, dark waves, shattered wood debris

segment_text: We waited long for news of the Lone Star of Savannah, but none ever reached us.
scene_description: outdoors, stormy ocean, dark waves, shattered wood debris

segment_text: We did at last hear that somewhere far out in the Atlantic a shattered stern-post of a boat was seen swinging in the trough of a wave, with the letters “L. S.” carved upon it, and that is all which we shall ever know of the fate of the Lone Star.
scene_description: outdoors, stormy ocean, dark waves, shattered wood debris
